results.title: Talk 16
results.creator_credit: Adrienne Mitchell, Janis Lundman, National Film Board of Canada and Back Alley Film Productions
results.brief_description: This is a most compelling and entertaining documentary about the personal lives of five young teenage girls aged between 15 and 16. Filmed over a one-year period, Janis Lundman and Adrienne Mitchell formed quite a remarkable bond with the girls, allowing the filmmakers to present an up-close and intimate insight into each of their lives. Meet Lina, Russian born, migrated to Canada with her family when she was 5 years old, inwardly rebellious and striving to be thought of as an adult by her family - her main aim in life is to find a boyfriend; Erin is from a middle-class family, attends private school, and wants to be a model but struggles with problems of body-image; Helen of Korean-born parents who are devout Christians and hold strict family values, is an honors student caught between two cultures; Astra, a runaway teenager, is an enigma - perceptive and articulate who considers herself a problem child, hates living by the rules and enjoys living on the edge, hanging out with druggies and ex-crims; Rhonda, brash, black and ambitious skips classes but will do anything to achieve her ambition to be an actress. From different socio-economic and cultural backgrounds, together these five young girls discuss sex, drugs, boyfriends, their future, feminism, beliefs and values, body image, and family with amazing frankness and humour. An interesting concept to see the changes in each of the girls over the year of filming. Voice and narration by Janis Lundman. (Award: Florida Film Festival 1994, Grand Jury Award)
results.creator_credit_for_label: Adrienne Mitchell, Janis Lundman, National Film Board of Canada and Back Alley Film Productions

results.title: Talk (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Doug Wilcox, Roger Owen and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Early years at school”
Stresses the importance of talking as a medium of communication for children aged three to nine years regardless of whether or not it takes the standard middle-class form.
Suitable for teacher/tertiary levels.

results.title: Talk
results.creator_credit: Susan Lambert, Megan McMurchy, Australian Film Commission and Suitcase Films
results.brief_description: Susan Lambert’s first feature film is a witty commentary on 90’s relationships and lifestyles. Two close women friends spend a day together. Their frank and funny conversations reveal hidden desires, erotic secrets, painful confessions and a bizarre fantasy that has unexpected results. Angie Milliken as Stephanie and Victoria Longley as Julia capture the strengths and confusion of women in their 30’s who mistakenly think they might want to trade lives. These women do not simply talk but, by the film’s conclusion, are empowered by their mutual support and easy confidence to act as well. Co-starring Richard Roxburgh, Jacqueline McKenzie and John Jarratt.

results.title: Taliesin East
results.creator_credit: James Davis, Wynant D Vanderpool and A.F. Films
results.brief_description: American architect, Frank Lloyd Wright had two homes. Talisen East, near Madison, Wisconsin and Taliesen West, near Phoenix Arizona. These homes illustrate Wright’s fundamental architectural principle, that buildings must blend with and seem to grow from their natural settings. Both structures reveal a conscious return to nature as inspiration for their design. ‘Awareness of environment’ says Wright ‘permits sustained original creation’. Taliesen East is a graceful structure, predominently in wood.
results.creator_credit_for_label: James Davis, Wynant D Vanderpool and A.F. Films

results.title: Talespinners
results.brief_description: CHRISTOPHER changes his name (prod. Tamara Lynch ; dir., animator, Cilia Sawadogo); A young boy decides to change his name many times but soon decides that his original name is just as good. Based on the book by Itah Sadu who also narrates the film. “Lights for Gita” (prod. Tamara Lynch ; dir. Michel Vo ; animator, Gregory Houston); A young girl is excited about celebrating Divali, an old Indian festival that fills the dark with the light. Her excitement soon ends because of a storm. Based on the book by Rachna Gilmore. “The Magic of Anansi” (prod. Tamara Lynch ; dir., animator, Jamie Mason ; animator, Luigi Allemano); Anansi a spider living in the jungle doesn’t think the other animals respected him so he sets out to gain the respect he deserves. Based on a West Indian tale and narrated by Winston Sutton. “From far away” (prod. Michael Fukushima ; dir., animators, Shira Avni, Serene El-Haj Daoud); A little girl tries to fit into a new school in a new country. Based on the book by Robert Munsch and Saoussan Askar. “CHRISTOPHER: please clean up your room!” (prod. Tamara Lynch ; dir., animator, Vincent Gauthier ; animator, Jo Meuris); A young boy manages to scare his family and friends with his messy room. This soon changes thanks to a few friends. Based on the book by Itah Sadu who also narrates the film.

results.title: Tales of the Taira Clan = Shin heiki monogatari
results.creator_credit: Kenji Mizoguchi, Masaichi Nagata and Daiei Motion Picture Company
results.brief_description: Set in twelfth-century Japan against a rich social and political background, this is an epic tale of power struggles, family drama, and human frailty. Mizoguchi lavished everything - sumptuous colour, elaborate sets and costumes - on this gripping drama, making his penultimate film - only one of two films he made in colour - a masterpiece. In Japanese with English subtitles.
results.title_for_label: Tales of the Taira Clan = Shin heiki monogatari

results.title: Tales of the Silk Road = Si Lu Hua Yu
results.creator_credit: Yan Xuesu and Xi'an Film Studio
results.brief_description:
The film is a dance drama which tells the story of a Dunhuang painter and his daughter on the ancient Silk Road. Painter Zhang saved Persian merchant Enus, who was nearly killed by a sand storm on the Silk Road. Zhang’s daughter, Yingniang, was seized by a bandit, Dou Hu, who made Yingniang a street dancer. Enus saw Yingniang on the street and saved her. In the Mogao Caves, taking his daughter as a model, painter Zhang completed a magnificent fresco portraying a dancing girl strumming a Pipa (a Chinese lute) behind her back. A local official was amazed by Yingnian’s beauty and wanted to get her. With no other choices, Zhang entrusted his daughter to Enus’ care. On Enus and Yingniang’s way back to Persia, the local official came with a gang of people to kill Enus. Zhang lit up a beacon fire to warn Enus and his daughter before he was dead in the desert. At the International Trade Fair held in Dunhuang, Yingniang sneaked in and exposed the local officer’s crime. The provincial governor was angry and ordered that the local officer be executed.

The film is based on the dance drama of the same title made in 1979. The 1979 dance drama was a great success and toured the country with nearly two hundred shows in 1980 alone. This is one of the most-performed dances in China. The film version of the dance is perhaps not as good as the actual stage performance. However, the film shows the audience the different styles of Chinese dancing and incorporates elements of other nations’ dancing styles. (3 stars - Yuxing Zhou; May 21, 2010)

results.title: Tales of the riverbank: morning mist
results.creator_credit: Paul Sutherland, McGraw-Hill Films and Riverbank Productions
results.brief_description: Hammy awakens to find that the river outside his house looks as though it were on fire. He decides to investigate, and heads upstream in a motor boat. He is soon engulfed in a white cloud, but the sun breaks through - it is the morning mist. Lost in a strange cave, Hammy is eventually rescued by Roddy and Guinea Pig.

results.title: Tales of the four seasons = Contes des quatre saisons
results.creator_credit: Eric Rohmer, Margaret Menegoz and Les Films du Losange
results.brief_description: A series of four films by Eric Rohmer on the theme of the four seasons, in which he continues his gentle studies of relationships in modern France.
